comment_text.mn124:1.1: Bakkula is depicted as an exponent of austerity who goes significantly beyond the norm in the early texts. According to the commentary, this sutta was added by the Elders at the Second Council, a century after the Buddha’s passing. This is supported by the lack of mention of where the Buddha is staying; by the advanced age of Bakkula; and by multiple textual indications. Bakkula apparently represents an ideal among a certain wing of the Saṅgha at that time. His verses in the Theragāthā, however, are simple and free from this severity (Thag 3.3).
comment_text.mn124:2.1: The phrase purāṇagihisahāya (“old friend from the lay life”) appears only here and at SN 41.9:1.1. There it is also said of a naked ascetic (acela) called Kassapa, which cannot be a coincidence. In that case he, as the former friend of the householder Citta, is the one interrogated, in a discourse set while the Buddha was still alive. The events of the present discourse happened many decades after the Buddha’s death, so it seems likely Kassapa was introduced as a conventional foil for Bakkula. Several such individuals named Kassapa are found in Pali, and their stories are conflated (DN 8, SN 12.17, SN 41.9).
comment_text.mn124:3.2: One may “go forth” at fifteen or “when old enough to scare crows” (Kd 1:51.1.14), so he is probably over ninety here.
comment_text.mn124:3.8: This repetition is found in the PTS and BJT editions, but missing from MS and King of Siam editions.
comment_text.mn124:3.10: According to the commentary, these responses were added by the Elders, representing praise of Bakkula’s austerities by the successful rigorist party at the Second Council. This is supported by several considerations. First, the commentators would rather claim something is early, so when they say it was added later it likely comes from a genuine tradition. Second, the refrains are in plural. Third, the refrains, and the statements of Bakkula that they answer, lack the close -ti indicating a direct quote. Fourthly, they continue after the conversation with Kassapa has concluded. The refrains are also found in the Chinese parallel. This shows how comparing different versions of a sutta can take us back only to the point where the texts diverge, which was some time after the Second Council. Thus a shared feature might have been added a century or more after the Buddha.
comment_text.mn124:9.1: From a discussion of mental purity, Bakkula proceeds to list a series of details of conduct, which are not morally reprehensible, but which illustrate his extreme commitment to austerity. | Accepting a robe from a householder implies enjoying the spoils of wealthy donors. Austere monks wore robes made of cast-off rags. Compare the story of Ānanda at MN 52:16.2 = AN 11.16:11.2, or at Kd 21:1.13.1, where he explained that after accepting quality robes, they were shared and reused. | This sutta can be seen as representing one of the disputing factions at the Second Council (Kd 22). The Saṅgha was divided between “rigorists” who advocated a more austere monastic life, and “laxists” who wanted to take a more relaxed attitude to discipline. The Second Council decided ten points of Vinaya in the rigorists’ favor, the most important of which was whether monastics could use money. Bakkula represents a rigorist position so extreme that if it were followed generally it would undermine the very existence of the Saṅgha. His severity, which even exceeds that of Mahākassapa, is implicitly contrasted with the gentle and accommodating spirit of Ānanda.
comment_text.mn124:10.1: The following items echo the Buddha’s concern at MN 122:2.8, where many monastics, including Ānanda, had gathered for making robes. | Note that most of these items are missing from the Chinese parallel at MA 34.
comment_text.mn124:11-15.4: This case is discussed in Bu Pc 46. It is normally forbidden to visit other families on the way to a meal invitation, but a special exemption is granted for the times of giving and making robes.
comment_text.mn124:16-19.1: Bakkula would eat only food collected on alms-round, refusing to eat a meal by invitation in a lay person’s home.
comment_text.mn124:16-19.4: This is allowed, but might sometimes get a monastic unwillingly involved in lay affairs (Bu Pc 43).
comment_text.mn124:20-25.1: This refers to the practice of sense restraint (MN 27:15.1). | For the grammar, see note on SN 35.235:1.4.
comment_text.mn124:20-25.2: Bu Pc 7 forbids teaching up to five or six lines to someone of the opposite sex, unless there is a chaperone present.
comment_text.mn124:20-25.3: This is stricter than Bu Pc 23, which forbids going to the nuns’s quarters for the purpose of giving the fortnightly instruction, with several exceptions noted.
comment_text.mn124:20-25.4: At MN 146:3.3, the Buddha encourages Nandaka to teach the nuns; indeed the Vinaya says that a monk should agree to teach the nuns (Kd 20:9.5.3), and in addition should go to the assistance of nuns (Kd 3:6.12.1). Compare Bu Pc 24, which forbids teaching nuns for the sake of material profits.
comment_text.mn124:26-29.1: Presumably Bakkula wished to avoid the responsibility of taking on students. If this practice was universally adopted, the Saṅgha could not survive.
comment_text.mn124:30-36.2: “Bath powder” (cuṇṇa) was in regular use (Kd 1:25.12.4), but was sometimes considered sensual (Kd 20:27.4.1).
comment_text.mn124:30-36.3: Massaging was done for health and by respect (Kd 12:1.1.27), but was often problematic, as it could be sexually arousing (Bu Ss 1:5.8.17) or even dangerous (Bu Pj 3:5.16.2). At one point the Buddha forbade massages for monks (Kd 15:1.4.1) and nuns (Bi Pc 90), although he allowed monks a “broad-handed” massage (Kd 15:1.5.6).
comment_text.mn124:30-36.4: Bakkula was said to be the foremost monk in good health (AN 1.226:1.1), an accolade that must have been added after his passing away. In later texts, he is often remembered for this (Tha Ap 398, Mil 5.5.3; Mahāprajñāpāramitāśāstra 8.2.3.3, Divyāvadāna 253.020). It would seem he mentions it here because many of the other items are allowed for the sake of health. It may happen that something such as a massage, which has a genuine health purpose, can become an indulgence.
comment_text.mn124:30-36.6: Allowed at Kd 16:20.2.15. This was a wooden plank that was leaned against the wall as a simple backrest.
comment_text.mn124:30-36.7: A simple bed was allowed (Bu Pc 16), but Bakkula slept on the ground.
comment_text.mn124:38.1: Said by Mahākassapa at SN 16.11:13.2. See MN 26:20.21 and note.
comment_text.mn124:40.1: The “latchkey” (avāpuraṇa) was a universal key inserted into outside doors to lift the bolt within (SN 22.90:1.2, AN 9.11:2.1). He took it to access the inner dwellings in the monastery to make his announcement.

root_text.mn124:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ āyasmā bākulo rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
root_text.mn124:2.1: Atha kho acelakassapo āyasmato bākulassa purāṇagihisahāyo yenāyasmā bākulo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā bākulena saddhiṁ sammodi.
root_text.mn124:2.2: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho acelakassapo āyasmantaṁ bākulaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn124:3.3: “Imehi pana te, āvuso bākula, asītiyā vassehi katikkhattuṁ methuno dhammo paṭisevito”ti?
root_text.mn124:3.4: “Na kho maṁ, āvuso kassapa, evaṁ pucchitabbaṁ:
root_text.mn124:3.5: ‘imehi pana te, āvuso bākula, asītiyā vassehi katikkhattuṁ methuno dhammo paṭisevito’ti.
root_text.mn124:3.6: Evañca kho maṁ, āvuso kassapa, pucchitabbaṁ:
root_text.mn124:3.7: ‘imehi pana te, āvuso bākula, asītiyā vassehi katikkhattuṁ kāmasaññā uppannapubbā’”ti?
root_text.mn124:3.9: “Asīti me, āvuso, vassāni pabbajitassa nābhijānāmi kāmasaññaṁ uppannapubbaṁ”.
root_text.mn124:3.10: “Yampāyasmā bākulo asītiyā vassehi nābhijānāti kāmasaññaṁ uppannapubbaṁ idampi mayaṁ āyasmato bākulassa acchariyaṁ abbhutadhammaṁ dhārema”.
root_text.mn124:4-5.1: “Asīti me, āvuso, vassāni pabbajitassa nābhijānāmi byāpādasaññaṁ …pe…
root_text.mn124:4-5.3: “Yampāyasmā bākulo asītiyā vassehi nābhijānāti vihiṁsāsaññaṁ uppannapubbaṁ, idampi mayaṁ āyasmato bākulassa acchariyaṁ abbhutadhammaṁ dhārema”.
root_text.mn124:6.1: “Asīti me, āvuso, vassāni pabbajitassa nābhijānāmi kāmavitakkaṁ uppannapubbaṁ”.
root_text.mn124:6.2: “Yampāyasmā bākulo asītiyā vassehi nābhijānāti kāmavitakkaṁ uppannapubbaṁ, idampi mayaṁ āyasmato bākulassa acchariyaṁ abbhutadhammaṁ dhārema”.
root_text.mn124:7-8.1: “Asīti me, āvuso, vassāni pabbajitassa nābhijānāmi byāpādavitakkaṁ …pe…
root_text.mn124:7-8.3: “Yampāyasmā bākulo asītiyā vassehi nābhijānāti vihiṁsāvitakkaṁ uppannapubbaṁ, idampi mayaṁ āyasmato bākulassa acchariyaṁ abbhutadhammaṁ dhārema”.
root_text.mn124:9.1: “Asīti me, āvuso, vassāni pabbajitassa nābhijānāmi gahapaticīvaraṁ sāditā”.
root_text.mn124:9.2: “Yampāyasmā bākulo asītiyā vassehi nābhijānāti gahapaticīvaraṁ sāditā, idampi mayaṁ āyasmato bākulassa acchariyaṁ abbhutadhammaṁ dhārema”.
root_text.mn124:10.1: “Asīti me, āvuso, vassāni pabbajitassa nābhijānāmi satthena cīvaraṁ chinditā”.
root_text.mn124:10.2: “Yampāyasmā bākulo asītiyā vassehi nābhijānāti satthena cīvaraṁ chinditā …pe… dhārema”.
root_text.mn124:11-15.1: “Asīti me, āvuso, vassāni pabbajitassa nābhijānāmi sūciyā cīvaraṁ sibbitā …pe…
root_text.mn124:20-25.2: nābhijānāmi mātugāmassa dhammaṁ desitā antamaso catuppadampi gāthaṁ …
root_text.mn124:37.1: “Asīti me, āvuso, vassāni pabbajitassa nābhijānāmi gāmantasenāsane vassaṁ upagantā”.
root_text.mn124:37.2: “Yampāyasmā bākulo asītiyā vassehi nābhijānāti gāmantasenāsane vassaṁ upagantā, idampi mayaṁ āyasmato bākulassa acchariyaṁ abbhutadhammaṁ dhārema”.
root_text.mn124:38.1: “Sattāhameva kho ahaṁ, āvuso, saraṇo raṭṭhapiṇḍaṁ bhuñjiṁ;
root_text.mn124:38.3: Yampāyasmā bākulo sattāhameva saraṇo raṭṭhapiṇḍaṁ bhuñji; atha aṭṭhamiyaṁ aññā udapādi idampi mayaṁ āyasmato bākulassa acchariyaṁ abbhutadhammaṁ dhārema.
root_text.mn124:39.1: Labheyyāhaṁ, āvuso bākula, imasmiṁ dhammavinaye pabbajjaṁ, labheyyaṁ upasampadan”ti.
root_text.mn124:39.2: Alattha kho acelakassapo imasmiṁ dhammavinaye pabbajjaṁ, alattha upasampadaṁ.
root_text.mn124:39.3: Acirūpasampanno panāyasmā kassapo eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
root_text.mn124:39.4: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
root_text.mn124:39.5: Aññataro kho panāyasmā kassapo arahataṁ ahosi.
root_text.mn124:40.1: Atha kho āyasmā bākulo aparena samayena avāpuraṇaṁ ādāya vihārena vihāraṁ upasaṅkamitvā evamāha:
root_text.mn124:40.3: “Yampāyasmā bākulo avāpuraṇaṁ ādāya vihārena vihāraṁ upasaṅkamitvā evamāha: ‘abhikkamathāyasmanto, abhikkamathāyasmanto; ajja me parinibbānaṁ bhavissatī’ti, idampi mayaṁ āyasmato bākulassa acchariyaṁ abbhutadhammaṁ dhārema”.
root_text.mn124:41.1: Āyasmā bākulo majjhe bhikkhusaṅghassa nisinnakova parinibbāyi.
root_text.mn124:41.2: “Yampāyasmā bākulo majjhe bhikkhusaṅghassa nisinnakova parinibbāyi, idampi mayaṁ āyasmato bākulassa acchariyaṁ abbhutadhammaṁ dhāremā”ti.

translation_text.mn124:1.2: At one time Venerable Bakkula was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
translation_text.mn124:2.1: Then the naked ascetic Kassapa, an old friend of Bakkula in the lay life, approached him, and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.mn124:2.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Venerable Bakkula,
translation_text.mn124:3.1: “Reverend Bakkula, how long has it been since you went forth?”
translation_text.mn124:3.3: “But in these eighty years, how many times have you had sex?”
translation_text.mn124:3.4: “You shouldn’t ask me such a question.
translation_text.mn124:3.6: Rather, you should ask me this:
translation_text.mn124:3.7: ‘But in these eighty years, how many times have sensual perceptions ever arisen in you?’”
translation_text.mn124:3.8: “But in these eighty years, how many times have sensual perceptions ever arisen in you?”
translation_text.mn124:3.9: “In these eighty years, I don’t recall that any sensual perception has ever arisen in me.”
translation_text.mn124:3.10: This we remember as an incredible and amazing quality of Venerable Bakkula.
translation_text.mn124:4-5.1: “In these eighty years, I don’t recall that any perception of ill will …
translation_text.mn124:4-5.2: or cruelty has ever arisen in me.”
translation_text.mn124:4-5.3: This too we remember as an incredible and amazing quality of Venerable Bakkula.
translation_text.mn124:6.1: “In these eighty years, I don’t recall that any thought of sensuality …
translation_text.mn124:7-8.2: or cruelty has ever arisen in me.”
translation_text.mn124:7-8.3: This too we remember as an incredible and amazing quality of Venerable Bakkula.
translation_text.mn124:9.1: “In these eighty years, I don’t recall accepting a robe from a householder …
translation_text.mn124:10.1: cutting a robe with a knife …
translation_text.mn124:11-15.1: sewing a robe with a needle …
translation_text.mn124:11-15.3: sewing a robe during the robe-making ceremony …
translation_text.mn124:11-15.4: wandering to look for robe material for my companions in the spiritual life when they are making robes …
translation_text.mn124:20-25.1: getting caught up in the features by way of the details of a lady’s appearance …
translation_text.mn124:20-25.2: teaching a lady, even so much as a four line verse …
translation_text.mn124:26-29.4: being looked after by a novice …
translation_text.mn124:30-36.3: looking for a massage from my companions in the spiritual life …
translation_text.mn124:30-36.4: being ill, even for as long as it takes to pull a cow’s udder …
translation_text.mn124:30-36.5: being presented with medicine, even as much as a bit of yellow myrobalan …
translation_text.mn124:30-36.8: This too we remember as an incredible and amazing quality of Venerable Bakkula.
translation_text.mn124:37.1: “In these eighty years, I don’t recall commencing the rainy season residence within a village.”
translation_text.mn124:37.2: This too we remember as an incredible and amazing quality of Venerable Bakkula.
translation_text.mn124:38.1: “Reverend, for seven days I ate the nation’s almsfood as a debtor.
translation_text.mn124:38.2: Then on the eighth day I became enlightened.”
translation_text.mn124:38.3: This too we remember as an incredible and amazing quality of Venerable Bakkula.
translation_text.mn124:39.1: “Reverend Bakkula, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in this teaching and training?”
translation_text.mn124:39.2: And the naked ascetic Kassapa received the going forth, the ordination in this teaching and training.
translation_text.mn124:39.3: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Kassapa, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn124:39.4: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”
translation_text.mn124:39.5: And Venerable Kassapa became one of the perfected.
translation_text.mn124:40.1: Then some time later Venerable Bakkula, taking a latchkey, went from dwelling to dwelling, saying,
translation_text.mn124:40.2: “Come forth, venerables, come forth! Today will be my full extinguishment.”
translation_text.mn124:40.3: This too we remember as an incredible and amazing quality of Venerable Bakkula.
translation_text.mn124:41.1: And Venerable Bakkula became fully extinguished while seated right in the middle of the Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn124:41.2: This too we remember as an incredible and amazing quality of Venerable Bakkula.
